discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
PG 251 you can speed routing convergence with lowerin gkeepable and hold timers.

Selected Answer: AC
1. link-down-failover (A)
This setting ensures that BGP reacts quickly to a link failure.
If a physical link goes down, the BGP session is immediately terminated instead of waiting for hold timers to expire.
This speeds up routing convergence by allowing faster failover to alternate paths.
2. holdtime-timer (C)
The hold-time timer determines how long a router waits before declaring a BGP peer dead if no keepalives or updates are received.
Lowering the hold-time value speeds up failure detection and convergence.
A typical BGP hold-time is 180 seconds, but reducing it to 30 or 60 seconds improves responsiveness.

Reference:

Study Guide P. 251

Selected Answer: AC
A & C - Se ginmco's comment.

Selected Answer: AC
A & C : Study guide SDWAN 7.2 page 251
A and C -Study Guide page 251

questions.question_text: Which two settings can you configure to speed up routing convergence in BGP? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The configuration shown in the image includes the Fortinet SD-WAN settings, specifically the load-balancing mode set to source-dest-ip-based, This means that SD-WAN will consistently send all traffic between a particular source IP and destination IP pair through the same interface.]

Selected Answer: B
SG p 177: "load-balance-mode source-dest-ip-based": "FG sens session *with the same source AND destination IP address pair* to the same member"

Selected Answer: B
The default load-balancing method is sourceIP but under the system sdwan 
is configured with sourc-dest-ip-based. What that means is that this load balancing method is applied to the implicit deny sdwan rule as well. 
So B is correct if it matches or not match any sdwan rules

B is correct
Source-Destination IP: FortiGate sends sessions with the same source and destination IP address pair to
the same member. (CLI source-dest-ip-based)

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
Note that the exhibit has the load balance mode set as "source-dest-ip-based" - the answer is B.

discussion.content:

Study Guide P176 : 

Source IP: This is the default algorithm. FortiGate sends sessions sourced from an IP address to the same member. (CLI source-ip-based)

The answer B use "Source-Destination IP" Algorithm and is not the default one.

choices.C: All traffic from a source IP is sent to the same interface.
choices.D: All traffic from a source IP to a destination IP is sent to the least used interface.
choices.A: All traffic from a source IP is sent to the most used interface.
choices.B: All traffic from a source IP to a destination IP is sent to the same interface.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibits.


Exhibit A -

//IMG//



Exhibit B -

//IMG//


Exhibit A shows two IPsec templates to define BranchIPsec_1 and Branch_IPsec_2. Each template defines a VPN tunnel.

Exhibit B shows the error message that FortiManager displayed when the administrator tried to assign the second template to the FortiGate device.

Which statement best explain the cause for this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. You can assign only one template with a tunnel of type static to each FortiGate device.

This best explains the issue because only one static IPsec template can be assigned per FortiGate, and the error occurs due to conflicting static tunnel templates. The (D) statement is too broad and not entirely correct because:
-FortiGate can support multiple IPsec templates, but not if they are both static.
If one of the templates were dynamic, it would be possible to assign multiple IPsec templates to the same FortiGate device.
-The error message specifically refers to a conflict due to static tunnel types, not because multiple templates are entirely forbidden.

Selected Answer: D
"One template per device; one or more tunnels per template"

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.

Selected Answer: D
Study Guide Page 59, One Template per device. D You can assign ONLE ONE IPsec TEMPLATE to each FortiGate DEVICE.

Selected Answer: D
One template per Device - One or multiple tunnels per template.. D

comments.content: Wrong. D is the correct answer. It is always the same Fortigate: branch1_fgt. There are two templates. But you can assign only one to the same device.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
well after futher reading, I change my answer to A, since in the statement say "second" , that is the reason the A refer to Hub 2.....

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer per Study Guide Page 59. One Template per FortiGate Device, you have multiple tunnels inside the template.

choices.A: You should review the branch1_fgt configuration for the already configured tunnel with the name HUB1-VPN2.
choices.D: You can assign only one IPsec template to each FortiGate device.
choices.C: You can assign only one template with a tunnel of type static to each FortiGate device.
choices.B: You can define only one IPsec tunnel from branch devices to HUB1.

choices.A: SD-WAN rules use SLA targets to check if the preferred members meet the SLA requirements.
choices.B: Member metrics are measured only if an SLA target is configured.
choices.C: When configuring an SD-WAN rule, you can select multiple SLA targets of the same performance SLA.
choices.D: SLA targets are used only by SD-WAN rules that are configured with Lowest Cost (SLA) or Maximize Bandwidth (SLA) as strategy.

questions.question_text: Which two statements about SLA targets and SD-WAN rules are true? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
A-correct
D-tested in lab

Selected Answer: AC
SLA targets can also be used in Best Quality strategy (which selects the best link based on SLA performance metrics).
Not limited only to Lowest Cost or Maximize Bandwidth.

Selected Answer: AD
SG p 197: "Manual: . . . metrics are not considered (packet-loss, latency, . . .)
SG p 199: "Best Quality: . . . SLA targets are not considered"
Therefore only Low Cost (SLA) and Maximize Bandwidth (SLA) strategies use SLA targets.

Perhaps that why they are the only strategies with "(SLA)" in the name . . .

Selected Answer: AD
C is wrong because you may select multiple sla targets but only from different performance sla. One target per performance sla.

Selected Answer: AD
A and D , Pag 216 StudyGuide 7.2

Selected Answer: AD
Study Guide p. 196 to 225

Selected Answer: AD
C is absolutely wrong although it sounds correct . Read carefully what it says. It says C. When configuring an SD-WAN rule, you can select multiple SLA targets of the same performance SLA. 
That is not true a performance SLA indeed can have multiple SLA targets but in the rule section you can not specify multiple SLA Targets as what you specify is the Performance SLA object which included many SLA targets. Also indeed you can specify many Performance SLAs as SLA targets but not individual sla targets from a single performance SLA. So they play games with the words....

Selected Answer: AD
A & D are correct

Selected Answer: AC
A. SD-WAN rules use SLA targets to check if the preferred members meet the SLA requirements.
SD-WAN rules are designed to ensure that the traffic is routed through the best possible link based on the defined SLA targets. These targets define the acceptable levels of performance, such as latency, jitter, and packet loss. If the preferred member does not meet the SLA requirements, the SD-WAN rule can select an alternative member that meets the criteria.
C. When configuring an SD-WAN rule, you can select multiple SLA targets of the same performance SLA.
In FortiGate, you can configure multiple SLA targets within an SD-WAN rule. This allows the rule to evaluate multiple performance criteria to determine the best link for traffic routing. For example, you can set multiple targets for latency, jitter, and packet loss, and the rule will use these targets to select the optimal path.

Selected Answer: AD
A & D are correct. Study guide pages 217 through 225 explain this.

questions.question_text: Which two statements about the SD-WAN zone configuration are true? (Choose two.)

choices.A: You can use the service-sla-tie-break setting to configure preferred member selection based on the best route to the destination.
choices.C: You can delete the default zones.
choices.D: An SD-WAN member can belong to two or more zones.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
default zone can't be deleted

Selected Answer: AB
Answer is A & B : 

C is false, you can't delete default zone
D is false, only one membre per zone
A & B Study guide page 85. C is wrong since you cant delete the default Zone and D is wrong since a member can be assigned to one zone only, page 85
